direction.raw_text: (V.O.) In order to show you how a big symphony orchestra is put together, Benjamin Britten has written a big piece of music, which is made up of smaller pieces that show you all the separate parts of the orchestra. As Lionel listens, three other children wander out of their bedrooms and down to the landing. The first is an eight-year-old boy in a bathrobe. He is Murray. The second is a nine-year-old boy in white boxer shorts and a white undershirt. He is Rudy. The third is a twelve-year-old girl in a cardigan sweater with knee-high socks and brightly polished, patent-leather shoes. She is Suzy. She carries a one-month-old striped kitten. The boys drop down to the floor next to their brother. They lie on their stomachs with their chins propped up on their fists, listening. Suzy sits in the windowsill. She opens a book called Shelly and the Secret Universe. There is an illustration on the cover of a young gymnast with a glowing amulet around her neck. Suzy starts to read -- then pauses. She lowers her book. She raises a pair of junior binoculars to her eyes. She looks out into the rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY A rickety, three-story, stone-and-shingle house on a hillside with turrets and a widow's walk. A weather vane swings creaking on the roof. Tree tops sway in a cluster below. The sea is almost invisible in the misting rain, and the mainland is a shadow across the sound. Suzy sits in the high window, watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The family stuck indoors all day out of the rain. In bedrooms, bathrooms, and corridors, we see the boys. They shoot marbles. They throw jacks. They play cards. They eat grilled cheese sandwiches together in the kitchen. In half-open doorways, we see the parents. Mr. Bishop is a tall, fifty-year-old man in Madras trousers and horn-rimmed glasses. He reads the newspaper and drinks coffee. Mrs. Bishop is a tan, forty-five-year-old woman in a Lilly Pulitzer-type wrap-around skirt. She washes her hair, topless, in the kitchen sink. In windows, we see Suzy with her binoculars. She watches wet branches shaking in the woods. She watches a man in a slicker fishing from a row-boat. She watches a white colt in a field. She eats a bowl of tomato soup alone in the pantry. In the distance, a seaplane flies by below the clouds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The edge of a cliff above a white beach. A rocky peninsula curls into the background. Brisk wind rustles the tall grass. A fifty-year-old man, bald on top with long hair on the sides, stands next to a surveyor's levelling instrument on a tripod. He wears rubber boots and a parka. He is the narrator. He speaks to the camera:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the island of New Penzance. Sixteen miles long. Forested with old- growth pine and maple. Criss-crossed by shallow tidal creeks. An important seabird habitat. There are no paved roads but instead many miles of intersecting foot paths and dirt trails and a ferry that runs twice daily from Stone Cove. The year is 1965. We are on the far edge of Black Beacon Sound, famous for the ferocious and well-documented storm which will strike from the east on the fifth of September -- in three day's time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY A clearing in the woods with ten small, khaki tents pitched in a row. A banner on a flag-pole ripples in the wind. It reads Camp Ivanhoe. A bugler in a khaki uniform with a yellow neckerchief plays a staccato tattoo. He has a gauze patch over one eye. He is Lazy-Eye. A thirty-five-year-old man in the same uniform emerges through the flaps of a larger tent. He is Scout Master Ward. He puts on a wide-brimmed felt hat. A badge on the crown reads Khaki Scouts, Troop 55. He lights a cigarette. A thin scout with curly hair and sunglasses joins him at his side. He is Gadge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning, Gadge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning, sir. Gadge flips open a small, spiral-bound note-book. Scout Master Ward goes over to a latrine made from thick sticks and rope. A tall, stooped scout digs a trench next to it with an army-shovel. He is Deluca.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Deluca. Latrine inspection. Deluca stops digging. He pulls on a rope and water runs down a chute. It bursts through a valve, spins a little door, and a small, red flag flips up. Scout Master Ward nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Gadge makes a note. Scout Master Ward strides away. He stops in front of a scout with long hair over his eyes sitting on a stump twisting something in his fingers. He is Roosevelt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roosevelt. How's that lanyard coming?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I think I skipped a stitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small, woven, multi-colored cord with a rabbit's foot attached to the end of it. It has been braided exceedingly badly and is brutally twisted and misshapen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Scout Master Ward studies the lanyard briefly. He looks perplexed. He pats Roosevelt on the back gently and does a secret handshake with him. Gadge makes a note. Scout Master Ward strides away. An off-road motorcycle races by in the background behind the tents. It jumps a mound of dirt, kicks sideways in the air, and revs away riding a wheelie. Scout Master Ward frowns. Scout Master Ward stops in front of a pile of boards and logs stacked six feet high. A thick-set scout with black hair and a crooked tooth approaches with more logs in his arms. He is Skotak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skotak. What's all this lumber for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're building a tree house. Skotak points up. Scout Master Ward squints. There is a small platform under construction about sixty feet above them. Two scouts are sawing something in half on it. Scout Master Ward looks astonished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not a safe altitude. Scout Master Ward circles around the trunk while looking up at the tree house. He stammers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why's it up so high? If somebody falls -- it's a guaranteed death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, where would you've built it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lower! Gadge makes a note. Skotak looks sheepish. Scout Master Ward strides away. He stops in front of a very small scout with tiny eyes poking at an anthill with a stick. He appears to be contemplating pouring lighter fluid on it. He is Nickleby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nickleby. Spot check. Nickleby stands up. He looks extremely disheveled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your socks are down. Your shirt-tails are untucked. Your trousers are not properly pressed. You are reported for uniform violation! Gadge makes a note. Nickleby slouches. Scout Master Ward strides away. He stops in front of a work-bench covered with newspaper where one scout sifts green powder through a funnel into cardboard tubes and another makes wax stoppers with a metal press. They are Panagle and Izod. A sign on the side of the table reads No Smoking. Scout Master Ward hands his cigarette to Gadge, who holds it away at arm's length.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many rockets you up to, Panagle?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sixteen and a half.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That enough for the Jubilee? Gadge shakes his head. Scout Master Ward turns to Izod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Izod, go fetch another pint of gun-powder from the armory shed. Izod dashes around the corner. Scout Master Ward strides away. He shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redford! Halt! The motorcycle skids to a stop in front of Scout Master Ward, engulfing him in a thick cloud of dust. He coughs and waves his arms in the air. As the smoke clears, we see that the rider is a bronze, all-American-looking boy with blond hair. He is Redford. His motorcycle has flames painted on the gas tank. He tries to cover for himself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Safety-test, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The vehicle appears to be in good working order. I'm just checking if -- 6.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reckless cycling. Second warning. Next time, I take away the keys. Gadge makes a note. Redford scowls. Scout Master Ward strides away. He walks past a scout in a white apron cooking bacon over a charcoal grill. He is Chef.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning, Chef. Chef rings a bell hanging on a post. Scout Master Ward arrives at a long picnic table. He sits down and opens a magazine called Indian Corn. There is a picture on the cover of a scout troop crossing a bridge in Indonesia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first page. A caption across the top reads Scout Master- in-Chief. There is a drawing of a seventy-year-old man on horseback. He has silver hair and a moustache. A signature below reads Commander Pierce. There is a quotation in large text: "An eagle was never hatched from a goose's egg." As Scout Master Ward reads, all the scouts begin to join him one-by-one. They range in age from twelve to fifteen. They unscrew the tops of tin mess-kits and assemble folding utensils. The chef brings a tray of scrambled eggs to the table. The scouts serve themselves noisily. Scout Master Ward starts to take a sip of coffee from a metal cup -- then stops. He looks up from his magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's missing? Scout Master Ward silently reels off a list of names, scanning the troop. He turns and shouts across the camp:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shakusky! Breakfast! Silence. Scout Master Ward calls to Lazy-Eye:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lazy-Eye. Lazy-Eye plays another tattoo. Silence. Scout Master Ward closes his magazine. He flicks his cigarette into a red bucket labelled Fire. He picks up a strip of bacon and chews on it as he rises to his feet and walks down the row of smaller tents. The last one is sealed
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . at the front. Scout Master Ward stands with his hands on his hips and says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shakusky? You in there? Scout Master Ward tugs on the tent's flaps. He frowns. He says to Gadge:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's zipped from the inside. The other scouts begin to gather with their tin breakfast plates in their hands, watching curiously while they eat. Scout Master Ward's voice softens:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam? Scout Master Ward looks concerned. He produces a wooden- handled scout pocket-knife. He unfolds a few blades and gadgets and decides quickly on a thin tool with a hook on the end. He crouches down and slips the hook through a small gap at the base of the flap, twists left and right, then pulls up briskly, unzipping the tent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The lining of the tent is printed with images of trees and pine cones, and a plaid rug covers the floor. There is a foot locker, a gas lamp, a chair with a folded blanket over it, and an empty cot. Scout Master Ward steps inside slowly, bent over, examining the space. He lifts the lid of the foot locker. He looks under the corner of the mattress. He picks up a piece of folded yellow notebook paper sticking out from under a pillow. He opens it and stares at it. He turns suddenly to the chair against the wall of the tent and slides it aside. There is neat but slightly jagged hole the size of a basketball cut through the fabric in the back corner. Scout Master Ward looks to his staring troop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jiminy Cricket. He flew the coop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY A one-room bungalow with a sign on the door that reads Island Police. There is a wood-panelled station wagon parked alongside it with roller-lights on the roof and a sheriff's office insignia on the door. (This is the only car on the island.) A dock stretches from the cottage into a small
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . harbor. There is a launch moored at the end of it which bobs in the rough tide. A silver Airstream trailer is parked under a tree nearby. A six-foot tall, forty-five-year-old man sits on a stool fishing from the side of the dock. He wears a short-sleeved police uniform with a black necktie and a baseball cap. His glasses have clear, plastic frames and a strap. He is Captain Sharp. Two grouchy, leathery, very old men in plaid flannel and hunting caps fish alongside Captain Sharp. A speaker on a post emits an electric buzz. Captain Sharp turns. He stands up briskly and says to one of the old men:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch my line, Edgar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY A small office with a desk, a file cabinet, and a two-way radio. Captain Sharp comes inside, sits down, grabs a microphone, and presses a red button on the side of it with his thumb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello? This is Captain Sharp. Over. Scout Master Ward's voice comes over a crackly speaker:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Captain Sharp, this is Randall Ward over at Camp Ivanhoe. Over. Captain Sharp pours himself a cup of coffee from a pot on a hot-plate as he answers distractedly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning, Randy. What can I do for you? Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I'm not sure, exactly. I've got an escaped Khaki Scout. Over. Silence. Captain Sharp frowns slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does that mean? Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) One of my boys seems to have stolen a dug- out and some fishing tackle, ten pounds (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (cont'd) of sundries, two bedrolls, plus an air rifle -- and disappeared. Over. Captain Sharp slowly stirs sugar into his coffee as he contemplates this. He says finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any idea why? Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) No. He left me a letter of resignation. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sheet of wide-ruled yellow paper which reads in a boy's
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear Scout Master Ward, I am very sad to inform you I can no longer be involved with the Khaki Scouts of North America. The rest of the troop will probably be glad to hear this. It is not your fault. Best wishes, Sam Shakusky. Captain Sharp scratches his head. He checks his watch. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess we better notify his folks. Over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Over and out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY A clapboard cottage surrounded by a white, picket fence. A sign on the door reads U.S. Mail. Captain's Sharp station wagon is parked in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY A young woman with her hair in a bun sits at an operator's switchboard eating a sandwich wrapped in wax-paper. She is Becky. She wears bulky head-phones with a microphone attached. Captain Sharp paces behind her. Scout Master Ward flips through a stack of letters and post cards. A bell rings on the switchboard. Becky plugs cords into sockets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Diane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Becky, I have your person-to-person from Chesterfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold the line, please. Becky signals to Captain Sharp and Scout Master Ward. They sit down quickly and put on their own sets of operator head- phones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead, Chesterfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Split-screen. On one side of the frame, we see Captain Sharp, Scout Master Ward, and Becky. On the other side, we see a seventy-five-year-old man with a grizzled face sitting at a kitchen table drinking coffee and smoking a cigarette while a white-haired woman ices a cake in the background. They are Mr. and Mrs. Billingsley. Mr. Billingsley says into his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, sir. This is Captain Sharp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY Yes, sir. I received your message. Thank you very much. In fact, we've come to a decision, as a family, because this is only the most recent incident involving Sam's troubles, and it's just not fair to the others, so, unfortunately -- we can't invite him back, at this time. Captain Sharp, Scout Master Ward, and Becky all look puzzled. Captain Sharp says evenly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no cause for alarm, sir. We'll find him. We're just notifying you as a matter of protocol and so on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY I understand that. I'm notifying you of the situation on my end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm confused by that statement. You can't invite him back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY I'm afraid not. He's a good boy, he's got a good heart, but it's just not fair to the others, you see? He's emotionally disturbed. Long pause. No one moves except Mrs. Billingsley icing her cake. Captain Sharp says finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I speaking to Sam's father? Mr. Billingsley frowns. He says, surprised:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY No, sir. Sam's parents passed away a number of years ago. We're Mr. and Mrs. Billingsley. We're foster parents. Sam's been with us since last June. Mrs. Billingsley has stopped icing her cake. She watches Mr. Billingsley. Scout Master Ward interjects:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, sir. This is Scout Master Ward speaking. Are you implying Sam's an orphan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY Well, it's a known fact. Of course, he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why the hell doesn't it say that in the register? Excuse my language. Scout Master Ward holds up a manila file-card. Mr. Billingsley shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY I don't know. What register?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The manila file-card. It is labelled Khaki Scout Register. Sam Shakusky is typed across the top line. There is an address, health information, and a small, faded snap-shot stapled to the corner of it of a twelve-year-old boy standing in a sunny tobacco field. He wears his scout uniform with a Davy Crockett-style coon-skin cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY We sent him a letter. It should reach you presently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Scout Master Ward looks quickly through his stack of letters. He stops and pulls out an air-mail envelope. He stares at it. Captain Sharp says forcefully but highly agitated:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Billingsley, I've got an escaped Khaki Scout. We're notifying you as a matter of protocol. You say you can't invite him back? You say he's an orphan? Well, I don't understand how that works. (TOTALLY CONFUSED) What am I supposed to do with him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BILLINGSLEY That's up to Social Services. They'll be in touch with you. They'll look after Sam. Good luck to you. Mr. Billingsley hangs up the telephone. Becky pulls the cords out of their sockets. Captain Sharp looks to Scout Master Ward. Silence. Becky opens a tin of home-made chocolate chip cookies. Captain Sharp declines one. Scout Master Ward tries one. He looks very impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Scout Master Ward stands on a bench addressing his assembled troop. The scouts are equipped for hiking with back-packs and walking-sticks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have your orders. Use the orienteering and path-finding skills you've been practicing all summer. Let's find our man and bring him safely back to camp. Remember: this isn't just a search party, it's a chance to do some first- class scouting. Any questions? Lazy-Eye raises his hand. Scout Master Ward points to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lazy-Eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your real job, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a math teacher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What grade?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eighth. Why? Lazy-Eye shrugs. Scout Master Ward frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, we're, actually, kind of, in the middle of something, if you didn't notice. This is a crisis. Anybody else? Redford raises his hand. Scout Master Ward points to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if he resists?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shakusky. Are we allowed to use force on him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you're not. This is a non-violent rescue effort. Your instructions are to find him, not to hurt him. Under any circumstances. Do I make myself understood? The scouts murmur their understanding. Scout Master Ward nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Pause. Scout Master Ward wheels back to Lazy-Eye:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to change my answer, in fact. This is my real job. Scout Master, Troop
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . That's us. I'm proud of that. The scouts look impressed but slightly lost. Scout Master Ward says finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be leery out there. OK, let's get started. Where's Snoopy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right here. Skotak holds up a leash attached to a wire-haired terrier. Scout Master Ward takes a sock with a fleur-de-lis on it out of a paper sack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give him the scent. Scout Master Ward hands the sock to Skotak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redford, Deluca, Nickleby, Lazy-Eye, and Gadge at the back of the group talking under their breath while Skotak waves the sock under the dog's nose:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard he ran away because his family died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard he never had any family in the first place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's probably why he's crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you one thing: if we find him, I'm not going to be the one who forgot to bring a weapon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, neither.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The troop moves in a wide line searching through a thicket of skinny trees. Redford carries a net and a giant tomahawk in a sling. Deluca has a large hunting knife tucked under his belt. Panagle holds a walking stick with a cluster of nails sticking out on the end of it. Nickleby, Izod, and Lazy-Eye all wear bows and quivers of arrows strapped to their backs. The wire-haired terrier strains at the end of a leash, sniffing down a foot-path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Scout Master Ward speeds up the river in a small boat with an out-board motor. He gives orders over a walkie-talkie. Gadge steers. Captain Sharp stands on the doorsteps of various big houses showing the snap-shot of the missing scout to: an elderly woman, a house-keeper, a group of children, a priest. They all shake their heads. Captain Sharp drives his station wagon down a beach, through a field, and over a bridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Captain Sharp stands at the front door talking with Mr. and Mrs. Bishop. Mr. Bishop holds a glass of red wine in one hand and an open bottle in the other. Mrs. Bishop looks slightly uneasy. They both study the snap-shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Camp Ivanhoe? That's all the way across the other side of the island. You really think a twelve-year-old boy could row this far in a canoe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most likely not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (with a shrug) It's possible, Counsellor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (SLIGHTLY IRRITATED) I disagree, Counsellor. It'd take him three days, at least.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP I don't think so. Two days, maximum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Well, I'm not going to argue about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be that as it may, will you let me know if you see anything unusual?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A binocular shot of Captain Sharp from overhead as he walks away down the front steps. He passes Lionel, Murray, and Rudy on their way up the path. They wear wet bathing suits and towels around their shoulders. Captain Sharp pats Rudy on the top of his head. He dries his hand on the leg of his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . trousers. He gets into his station wagon, backs out of the driveway, circles through the woods, and drives around to a small dirt road a hundred yards behind the house. He stops the car. He gets out, sits on the hood, and lights a cigarette. Suzy watches from the widow's walk with her binoculars. She lowers them. She looks curious. She raises them back to her eyes and sees: Mrs. Bishop from overhead as she comes out the back door of the house carrying a basket of damp laundry. She pauses at a clothesline, looks left and right, then walks quickly into the trees. She crosses a foot-bridge and arrives at the dirt road. Captain Sharp stands up. They talk briefly but intensely. Mrs. Bishop leans against the car and stares into space. Captain Sharp touches her hair. Mrs. Bishop makes a gesture with her fingers. Captain Sharp hands her his cigarette. Mrs. Bishop takes a puff, hands it back, and strides away again through the woods. Captain Sharp gets into his station wagon and drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A portable night stand. There is a reel-to-reel tape recorder recording on it. A framed photograph next to it shows the Scout-Master-in-Chief posing with a troop in front of the Matterhorn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT The front flaps are tied-open, and a mosquito net is drawn. A hanging lantern flickers on a hook. A bugle plays a variation of taps in the distance. Scout Master Ward sits on a cot dressed in pajamas. He smokes a cigarette and drinks a glass of brandy while he speaks tensely into a microphone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scout Master's log. September second. First day of search party for Sam Shakusky. Morale is extremely low, in part, I suppose, because Sam is, unfortunately, the least popular scout in the troop, by a significant margin. I'm worried, and I'm confused. Please, let us find him tomorrow. Please, don't let him fall off a cliff or drown in the goddamn lake or something. A terrible day at Camp Ivanhoe. Let's hope tomorrow's better. In fact, I'm going to say a prayer. Scout Master Ward presses stop. He kneels down on the floor, closes his eyes, presses his palms together, and whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Scout Master Ward zips up his tent and turns off the light. Crickets chirp. Bats circle. The wire-haired terrier digs carefully through a pile of trash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The next morning. A fast current runs along a shallow ravine deep in the forest. The boy from the snap-shot rows a mini- canoe painted with Native American tribal symbols and severely over-loaded with boxes, bags, and blankets. He wears a pellet gun slung on a strap over his shoulder and his coon- skin cap. He smokes a pipe. A sash across his chest is decorated with numerous small, embroidered patches. There is a woman's enamelled brooch pinned to his shirt. It is a jeweled, black scorpion. He whistles to himself quietly as he steers under a fallen tree-trunk and winds through gentle rapids. He is Sam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY An eddy under a willow tree. The end of the canoe is tied to a branch, and the cargo is stacked on the shore. Sam covers the boat with a camouflage net and dresses the top with pine- needles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Sam hikes through a pass wearing an extremely large back-pack with stakes, metal poles, and two bed-rolls strapped to the bottom. He wears a compass on a string around his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A binocular shot of Sam emerging from the woods into a wide meadow. The grass comes up to his chest and flows in waves. He pauses to check his compass. He spins slowly one direction and then back the other while he stares at the dial. He looks up again. He walks onward. He stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WIDE MEADOW. DAY Suzy lowers her binoculars. She stands at the end of a path cut through the high grass. She has a leather folder in one hand, the portable record player in the other, plus a small suitcase and her kitten in a basket at her side. Sam takes his coon-skin hat slowly off his head. He strides across the meadow. Suzy watches him approach. She swallows. Her lips part. Sam comes onto the path. He stops ten feet away from Suzy. Sam and Suzy stare at each other. Silence. (NOTE: Suzy is slightly taller than Sam.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A poster box with St. Jack's Church across the top. A purple- ink mimeographed page is stapled to a bulletin board inside under the heading Summer Pageant, 1964. It reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Performed by the Choristers of St. Jack Wood and New Penzance
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dusk. A brick church at the top of a bluff overlooking the bay. It is overgrown with ivy and wisteria. There is a cemetery with a low wrought-iron fence. An organ plays inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One Year Earlier
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING A play is in progress. The set includes a long ark with a sail built on a platform behind the altar. Two teenagers crouched in the wings ripple a narrow, blue sheet across the foot of the stage. (This is meant to be water.) The rest of the room is dim, with tall candles flickering along the center aisle. The beams are draped with garlands. A large congregation fills every pew plus folding chairs against the walls. More people sit and stand on the steps to the choir loft at the back and in nooks and corners. The members of a brass ensemble seated beside the organist wait for their next cue, following their sheet music with instruments poised. Khaki Scouts and scout masters occupy the rear section of the church. A very young troop in a slightly different version of the uniform fills a row near the exit. Sam sits on the aisle. He looks bored. A baritone built like a linebacker in robes and a fake beard sings ominously on the stage. Cymbals crash. Sam stands up and discreetly wanders toward the side door with his hands in his pockets. A slight, forty-year-old man in the same uniform watches him from the end of the pew, frowning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam quietly entering the lobby. The sound of the music deadens as he gently shuts the door behind him. He turns around and puts on a yellow scout cap with Junior Khaki stitched on the bill. The room is jammed with children dressed as animals, waiting nervously in a long line that
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . winds all around the space. They whisper and shuffle. A large woman stares through a small window into the church with her hand on a doorknob. She is Mrs. Lynn. She snaps her fingers suddenly without looking to the children. They fall silent. Pause. Mrs. Lynn swings open the center doors. Music fills the room again. The first twenty of the children begin to sing. They march out of the lobby, two by two. The woman closes the doors behind them, and the next group takes their place to wait. Sam walks slowly among otters, monkeys, squirrels, and skunks, examining their costumes, periodically touching horns, tusks, and teeth. No one pays attention to him. He drinks a sip from a water fountain. He picks up a mint from a bowl and sucks on it. He slips out through a swinging door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING Sam moves down a dark corridor. Voices murmur. He pokes his head around a corner. A rack of choir robes and cassocks blocks his path. He slides two of them apart and looks
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five eleven-year-old girls in black leotards sitting on a bench in front of a mirror framed with light bulbs. They talk quietly and fix their make-up. They all wear wings on their arms and beaks on their heads. Suzy sits among them in black feathers. Sam stares at her. He steps into the light silently. Suzy sees him in the reflection. The other girls turn around quickly, covering themselves. Sam removes his cap and takes another step forward. His eyes dart briefly among the other girls. He says to Suzy:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of bird are you? Suzy hesitates. She looks to the girl next to her, who says in a bossy voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a sparrow, she's a dove, and -- Sam does not look away from Suzy as he interrupts, pointing:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I said, "What kind of bird are you?" The other girls all look to Suzy. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a raven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Suzy lifts her beak slightly higher on her forehead. The other girls look annoyed but transfixed. The bossy girl frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy's aren't allowed in here. Sam does not look away from Suzy as he answers quietly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be leaving soon. Sam points down at Suzy's lap. One of her hands is wrapped in a bandage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to your hand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got hit in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really. How'd that happen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I lost my temper at myself. Sam is deeply intrigued by this. The other girls look puzzled. Suzy presses her hair back off her face. She watches Sam nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam. What's yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Suzy. Sam nods with his eyes still glued to Suzy's. Suzy bites her fingernails. The bossy girl rolls her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not polite to stare. Sam holds up his hand for the bossy girl to stop talking. Mrs. Lynn steps into the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LYNN Birds! Ready?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mrs. Lynn does a double-take. She snaps at Sam:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LYNN Who are you? Where'd you come from? Go back to your seat. Sam hesitates. He spits the mint into a trash can, ducks out through the clothing rack, and is gone. A skinny girl dressed as an owl watches Suzy while the other girls hurry to their feet. She says quietly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He likes you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING Troops flood out from one side of the church while children in animal costumes flood out from the other. They criss-cross among grave-markers and head-stones. Sam stops abruptly, face to face with the skinny owl. She whispers something, points behind her, and thrusts a folded scrap of paper into Sam's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT A vehicle crowded with scouts. Sam sits alone in the back row. He stares into space, entranced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzy on-stage at the top of a pedestal with her arms in the air, spreading her wings. She is surrounded by the entire cast of singing animals. The music soars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam as he looks down at the piece of paper in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sheet of pink stationary with an address in a girl's red felt-tip cursive and the words: Write to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The present. Sam and Suzy face each other in the wide meadow. Sam says carefully:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you followed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I doubt it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Sam frowns and squints. He points.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you bring a cat? Suzy nods. Sam smiles. Suzy smiles. Sam takes a folded map out of his pocket. He signals for Suzy to come closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you read a map?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-huh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do cartography. Sam points to one of the patches on his sash. It has a protractor embroidered on it. He unfolds the map.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel we should go halfway today and halfway tomorrow, since you're a less experienced hiker, and you're wearing Sunday-school shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pointing on the map) Here's where we are right now. I'd like to pitch camp here by sixteen-hundred (which means four o'clock). How does that sound?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want some beef jerky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sam tears a strip of dried meat in two and gives half to Suzy. She tries to chew on it. Sam nods:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam and Suzy walk together down a hill, across a field, and through a wooded path eating beef jerky. They both smile continuously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you thirsty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if your throat gets parched, stick a pebble in your mouth and suck on it. You can quench your thirst with the spit, supposedly. Sam shows Suzy some bits of green and yellow sticking out from under his coonskin cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes I stick leaves under my hat. It cools your head down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a good idea. It might help also if you didn't wear fur.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True, but this adds camouflage. Sam stands in a clearing and pulls a handful of dry grass. He holds it in his fist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's a trick. Throw grass in the air, and you can see which direction the wind's blowing. Sam throws up the grass. It swirls and drifts vaguely. Suzy squints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unknown. I guess it doesn't really matter, as long as we cover our tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sam and Suzy stop to investigate and discuss: a patch of mushrooms, moss on a stump, ferns, poison ivy, and a low bush with purple fruit. Sam looks skeptical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These might be poisonous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, they're huckleberries, in fact. Try one. Suzy brushes off some dirt and eats a berry. Sam puts one into his mouth and nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not bad. Anyway, they're good for survival. Sam and Suzy look through Suzy's binoculars at a deer drinking from a stream. Suzy whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He knows someone's watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree. Why do you say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I just think he can feel us. Sam and Suzy walk across a fallen tree over a stream. A snake swims on the surface below them. Sam assists Suzy onto the far bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You smell like perfume.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my mother's. Sam picks up two pebbles. He and Suzy both put them in their mouths. They click against their teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I brought water, too. Sam and Suzy watch a small, green worm wriggling in the air, swaying from a silk thread. They stare, wide-eyed. Suzy cups her hand a few inches below it and moves it around in a circle. Sam shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should we catch him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trout bait. We need worms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Pause. The worm curls and uncurls itself gently. Sam nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. We'll let him live. Maybe I've got a licorice whip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The banks of a large pond. All of Sam's and Suzy's bags, boxes, and suitcases are arranged around a small tent decorated with more tribal symbols. The kitten is asleep. Sam and Suzy stand at the water's edge as he removes the camouflage net from the canoe and says gravely:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How strong of a swimmer are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pretty good. I broke our school record for the back-stroke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: OK. Well, I'm not that strong of a swimmer, so I wear a life-preserver. I think it's a good policy to get in the habit, anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sam and Suzy both strap on vests belted with cork blocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A strip of bright red licorice on a hook under water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sam and Suzy in the middle of the lake. Suzy sits at one end of the canoe fishing with a bamboo pole. Sam drapes his fingers off the side and stirs the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch out for turtles. They'll bite you, if you put your fingers in their mouths. Let me see if I can catch this one. Sam dips a net into the lake and brings it up with a small turtle in it. He lifts it out of the net. It has red and yellow markings and a slightly damaged shell. Sam flips it over. The word Albert is written on the underside of the turtle in magic marker. Sam says blankly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody wrote on him. The fishing pole jerks in Suzy's hands. She yells:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stick's moving!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got one! Sam jumps to his feet and heaves the turtle with two hands. It sails through the air across the pond and splashes down with a whack. Sam yells an announcement:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fish on hook! (TO SUZY) Reel him in! Slowly. The canoe rocks violently. Suzy snaps:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down! Sam sits back down. Suzy winds the reel carefully. Sam says,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're doing good. Sam points to one of the patches on his sash. It has a rod and reel embroidered on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is for fishing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK Sam twists a stick with a shoelace in kindling and builds a small camp-fire circled with rocks. He cooks two fish with bologna in a frying pan over a camp-fire. He throws in a dash of salt, grinds some pepper, and flips the fish in the air. He holds out a bite on a spatula to Suzy sitting on a log next to him. She tastes it. She looks surprised and nods
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good. You know a lot about camping, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a Khaki Scout. It's what I'm trained for. Sam points to one of the patches on his sash. It has fried eggs and bacon on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway, I used to be. Sam serves the fish onto two tin plates. He says as they eat with folding forks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can feed your cat the guts and eyeballs. Sam points to a pile of bloody organs and bones on a page of newspaper. Suzy frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's OK. He only eats cat food. Suzy points to a cardboard box. Sam looks inside. It is filled with ten cans of cat food. Sam raises an eyebrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What else did you bring? We should make an inventory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sam flips open a small, spiral-bound note-book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Suzy opens the top of her portable record player. She displays it like a salesman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is my record player. It works with batteries. Actually, it belongs to my little brother Lionel. I left him a note. Do you like music? Sam nods and makes a note. Suzy opens her leather folder. There are three L.P. records in it. She takes out one by a French singer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is my favorite record album. My godmother gave it to me for my birthday. She lives in France. Sam nods and makes another note. Suzy opens her suitcase. It is filled to the brim with hard-back copies of fantasy books. It contains no other items of any kind (including clothing).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are my books. I like stories with magic powers in them. Either in kingdoms on earth or on foreign planets. Also, time-travel, if they make it realistic. Usually, I prefer a girl hero, but not always. I couldn't bring all of them because it got too heavy. You can borrow any you want. Sam nods and makes another note. Suzy produces a few more
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I also brought my lefty scissors because I'm left-handed, my toothbrush, some rubber bands, extra batteries, and my binoculars, as you know. I forgot my comb. Sam surveys the entire collection of articles. He scratches his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it? No mess-kit? No flashlight? No canteen? No waterproof matches? Didn't you get the packing list I sent you in my last letter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought that's what you're supposed to bring. I don't own a canteen. Pause. Sam shrugs. He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's OK. We can share. Sam picks up one of the books. It is called The Girl from Jupiter. There is an illustration on the cover of a young, alien princess with glittering tears on her cheeks. Sam examines the other books in the suitcase. He looks slightly puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are all library books. In my school you're only allowed to check-out one at a time. Some of these are going to be overdue. Sam hesitates. He suddenly realizes something. He asks
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you steal? Silence. Suzy nods reluctantly. Sam looks confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? You're not poor. Suzy stares at the books. She absently brushes some dust off them. She rearranges them slightly. She says finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might turn some of them back in one day. I haven't decided yet. I know it's bad. I think I just took them to have a secret to keep. Anyway, for some reason, it makes me feel in a better mood sometimes. Sam thinks about this. He leans his chin against his fist. He
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you depressed? Suzy bites her fingernails. She shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Pause. Suzy says philosophically:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I can show you an example, if you want -- but it doesn't make me feel very good. I found this on top of our refrigerator. Suzy looks into her leather folder and shuffles through some pages. She withdraws a small pamphlet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cover of the pamphlet. There is a drawing of a broken tea- cup and the title "Coping with the Very Troubled Child". Sam frowns. His eyes widen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does that mean you? Suzy nods. Sam explodes with laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To me, it is. Sam slaps his knee and shakes his head. Pause. Suzy dumps her fish into the campfire and throws her metal plate like a frisbee into a tree trunk. It bounces off with a ding. She stands up and says coolly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really know how to make friends. Suzy walks away. She goes behind a bush and sits down on a rock. She starts to cry. Sam looks stricken and confused. He is very still. He gets up slowly. He tentatively approaches the bush. He looks behind it. He takes two steps closer. He stands above Suzy. He unties his neckerchief, crouches down, and holds it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Suzy looks to Sam. She hesitates. She takes the neckerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's OK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm on your side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Suzy dries her eyes. She unfolds the neckerchief and studies its design. It is a brave shooting an arrow while leaning off the side of a galloping horse. Sam motions to the books:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which one's the best?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dusk. Sam lies on his back on one of the bedrolls smoking his pipe while Suzy sits Indian-style next to him. She reads aloud from a book called The Francine Odyssies. There is an illustration on the cover of an enormous panther with a bloody sword walking behind a small girl in a nightgown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes downcast, his kingdom in ruins, Mynar pressed his heavy paw through the rippling surface of the cool shallows and down to its stone floor. "My people once were lead by a great and noble beast -- and I no longer see his face in this reflection." Suzy looks to Sam. He is asleep. She takes the pipe out of his mouth and tips the ashes into the camp-fire. She draws a blanket over his chest. She continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, on the Plains of Tabitha, Francine rested. There would be another time for war.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT The dining room. There is a long, wide, empty table with sixteen chairs around it. Tucked in the corner, Lionel, Murray, and Rudy sit at a folding card table. They have plates on place-mats and forks and knives. There is one extra seat. Mrs. Bishop's voice booms, amplified, from the next
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (O.S.) Suzy! Dinner! I'm not going to say it again! Pause. Mrs. Bishop charges into the room with a steaming casserole. She wears an oven mitt on one hand and carries an electric megaphone in the other. She sets the casserole on the card table and looks out the window. Through the thicket
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . of trees behind the house, a pair of headlights blinks. Mrs. Bishop checks her watch. She says sharply:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Where's your sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, but she borrowed my record player for ten days without asking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (CONFUSED) What does that mean? Lionel holds up a small, folded-up piece of pink stationary. Mrs. Bishop snaps it out of his hand and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A short note on pink stationary in a girl's red felt-tip cursive. It reads: Dear Lionel, I need to use your record player. I will give it back in ten days or less. Do not tell Mom. (Or Dad.) I will replace the batteries when I return. Signed, Suzy Bishop Mrs. Bishop frowns. She bolts back out of the room. Her voice
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (O.S.) Walt! Where the hell are you? There is a loud thump upstairs. Mr. Bishop shouts from
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (O.S.) Right here! Why are you cursing at me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exterior. Mr. Bishop leans out of an upstairs window. Mrs. Bishop appears in one below. She yells up through the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Does it concern you that your daughter's just run away from home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (PAUSE) That's a loaded question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mrs. Bishop brandishes the note with her free hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Come down and read this. A radio squawks in the woods behind the house. Mr. and Mrs. Bishop turn quickly toward the sound. Mrs. Bishop looks tense. Becky's garbled voice says over a tinny speaker:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Scout Master Ward confirms they've had no luck. They're going home for the -- There is a rustling and the sound of a car door opening -- then the radio cuts off. Mr. Bishop frowns. He shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Who's there? Captain Sharp emerges slowly from the dark, tangled in a bramble, hopping slowly on one foot as he unwinds a root from around his ankle. He smiles awkwardly and says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening. Sorry to startle you. I was
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (ANGRILY) What are you doing here? Nobody called the police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, that's what I'm saying. The search party's not over yet. In other
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Suzy's missing, too! Go find her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: OK. Where'd she -- MR. BISHOP Wait for me. Mr. Bishop disappears into the house. Captain Sharp and Mrs. Bishop exchange an uncertain look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Captain Sharp pans a spot-light back and forth in the darkness while he steers the car. The lamp has a short in it
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . and flickers with each bump. Mr. Bishop rides in the passenger seat. He stares ahead down the road and says to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP How can we help her? She's got so many problems. It's getting worse. Mr. Bishop looks strangely to Captain Sharp. He asks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Whose fault is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, but just for the record: ninety-five percent of all runaways return home within six hours. That doesn't do you any good right now. It's just a statistic -- but in all likelihood Suzy's probably hiding in the closet at her best friend's house playing Chinese Checkers at this very moment, as we speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP She doesn't have any friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's Laura?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (IRRITATED) How's Laura?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Bishop, I mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is she upset? Mr. Bishop looks baffled and disgusted. He throws his hands into the air. He looks away and shakes his head. Silence. Captain Sharp wiggles some wires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got to get this spot-light fixed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Captain Sharp and Mr. Bishop come to a stop and get out of the station wagon. They look dejected. The screen door bangs open, and Mrs. Bishop quickly descends the front steps with a open shoebox full of letters in her hands. She says breathlessly, shouting:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP She has a pen pal! It's very intimate! They planned this together! Captain Sharp takes one of the letters and studies it. He says to himself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam Shakusky. That's my escaped Khaki Scout. His family died. Mr. Bishop takes a handful of the letters and flips through them. He stops suddenly. He looks horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Holy Christ. What am I looking at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small painting on construction paper of a naked girl stepping into a bathtub. She wears a flower in her hair. Mrs. Bishop continues to shout as she explains:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP He does watercolors! Mostly landscapes, but a few nudes! Lionel, Murray, and Rudy watch from a downstairs window. Lionel takes a bite from a bowl of melting ice cream. Mr. Bishop stares at the painting. He squints at it and asks
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP She sit for this? Captain Sharp and Mrs. Bishop look over Mr. Bishop's shoulder. Captain Sharp says calmly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does he say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The history of Sam and Suzy's correspondence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sam, dressed in a greasy jump-suit, writes at a work bench in a garage while six teenagers take apart carburetors behind him. They are his foster brothers. Sam reads in voice-over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Suzy, You have a superb voice. You were my favorite animal in the program, by far. Please, find enclosed -- Suzy writes at a small desk on the upstairs landing while Lionel and Murray play a loud duet on a red piano behind her. (Rudy turns the pages of the sheet music.) Suzy reads in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Sam, Thank you very much. I got replaced as the raven because I yelled at Mrs. Lynn. After that I was only a blue jay, but -- Sam works in an alley emptying garbage from several small trash cans into a larger one. Mr. Billingsley watches television in a window, smoking a cigarette. He points to a crumpled wrapper on the ground. Sam picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Suzy, I am sorry your brothers are so selfish. Maybe they will grow out of it. Sometimes people do things without knowing the reasons for -- Suzy reads a book called Disappearance of the 6th Grade. There is an illustration on the cover of a school-teacher levitating at the front of her classroom. There are several watercolor pictures taped to the wall behind her. Most are landscapes of small-town vacant lots. One is a swimming girl in a bikini.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Sam, You are an excellent painter, especially trees and telephone poles. Is the girl in the water supposed to be me? My favorite color is -- Sam stands in pajamas staring blankly, eyes wide, at a dog house in flames next to a rusty swing-set. A dachsund sits next to him, also watching. Mrs. Billingsley comes running out of the house with a fire extinguisher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Suzy, I accidentally built a fire while I was sleep-walking. I have no memory of this, but my foster parents think I am lying. Unfortunately, it is -- 37. Suzy stands in the kitchen looking out through a pane of glass with a hole smashed in the middle of it. Mrs. Bishop is next to her with her hair hanging over the sink while the two of them carefully pick bits of glass out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Sam, I am in trouble again because I threw a rock through the window. My mother still has glass in her hair. Also -- Five of Sam's foster brothers watch calmly as the sixth throws Sam against the wall then jumps on top of him, pinning his arms to the floor while Sam struggles crazily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Suzy, I have been trying very hard to make friends, but I feel people do not like my personality. In fact, I can understand why they might -- A classroom of sixth graders watches in a panic as Suzy throttles one of her classmates. The classmate flails and grimaces as she is strangled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Sam, Now I am getting suspended because I got in a fight with Molly. She says I go berserk. Our principal is against me. Why do -- Sam does sit-ups on a hard mattress in a basement room lined with bunks. He counts out the repetitions under his breath. There is a small, black and white photograph of a man and woman at their wedding tacked to the wall above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Suzy, I know your parents hurt your feelings, but they still love you. That is more important. If they -- Suzy stands in a doorway screaming at her family while they watch wearily from the dinner table with forks and knives in their hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Sam, I do think you should think of their faces every day, even if it makes you sad. It is too bad they did not leave you more pictures of themselves. Can you -- Sam writes in his bunk crouched beneath a blanket with a Khaki Scout flashlight pointed at his paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Suzy, Here is my plan. Suzy writes in her bed crouched beneath a quilt with a plastic lantern glowing beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Sam, My answer is yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sheet of wide-ruled yellow paper which reads in a boy's
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Suzy, When?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sheet of pink stationary which reads in a girl's red felt-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Sam, Where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzy kneeling in the dark, crouched in front of an upper window with the shoebox of letters beside her. Outside, the woods are black beyond a moonlit field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Dear Suzy, Walk four hundred yards due north from your house to the dirt path which has not got any name on it. Turn right and follow to the end. Suzy raises her binoculars to her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I will meet you in the meadow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WIDE MEADOW. DAY The next morning. The end of the path cut through the high grass where Sam and Suzy met the day before. Captain Sharp, Scout Master Ward, Mrs. Bishop, and Becky stand in two groups talking. Gadge and Skotak stretch a string with ribbons tied to it from stake to stake marking a perimeter. Lazy-Eye walks with the wire-haired terrier pulling at its leash. Other scouts search the field and scan the horizon. Captain Sharp's station wagon and Redford's motorcycle are parked in the dirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mr. Bishop stands off to the side by himself poking at the ground with a stick. He has two black eyes, and half his face is swollen and purple. Scout Master Ward asks Becky quietly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure. I think he went searching in the dark. Mr. Bishop says loudly without looking up from the ground:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP She stole the batteries out of my flashlight. Scout Master Ward looks at Becky and grimaces. Becky raises an eyebrow. Mrs. Bishop stands next to Captain Sharp. They move slightly away from the others. Captain Sharp whispers quickly, almost inaudibly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think he's onto us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (INSTANTLY) Of course, he is. Captain Sharp looks surprised and defensive. He whispers
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, he is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Of course, he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why aren't we worried about that, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I didn't know. Or, anyway, I thought I was wrong. Did you hit him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP No. He fell in a ditch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Nickleby pops up from below the tall grass and thrusts an empty can of cat food into the air. He shouts excitedly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cat food! I think it's a clue. The group quickly gathers around Nickleby. Mr. Bishop snatches the can out of his hand and examines it. He says
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP That's her. Mr. Bishop throws the can away over his shoulder and walks off with his hands in his pockets. Nickleby runs after the can and picks it up again. Mr. Bishop continues down the hill. Scout Master Ward watches him. He asks Mrs. Bishop,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's he going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP I don't know. Mrs. Bishop follows Mr. Bishop. Captain Sharp turns to the rest of the group and says briskly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. We know they're together. We know they're within a certain radius of this spot. I'm declaring the case with the county right now. Until help arrives: Captain Sharp looks to Scout Master Ward as he points to various scouts and divides the group into teams:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm deputizing the little guy, the skinny one, and the kid with the curly hair to come with me in the station wagon. Randy, you drop-in and head up-river with the rest of your troop, then split-up on foot. Becky, call Jed and tell him to circle over this end of the island and fly low.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A binocular shot of the seaplane flying in a pattern. It banks sharply. The binocular shot tilts down. Far below, in the distance, Captain Sharp's station wagon rumbles along a dirt road through the woods. The binocular shot pans wide. On the side of the river, Scout Master Ward's motorboat stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Two scouts, tiny figures, pull the camouflage net off the hidden canoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Suzy watches through her binoculars while Sam crouches beside her. They are hidden behind a pile of rocks. Suzy says
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They found the canoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angry at himself) Rats! I should've put more pine needles on it. Let's go. We're almost there. Sam lifts his backpack onto his back and slings his air-rifle over his arm. Suzy picks up her suitcases and puts the kitten on her shoulder. They walk down a narrow path through a thicket. They emerge into a small clearing. Sam and Suzy stop in their tracks. Deluca, Nickleby, Panagle, Izod, and Lazy-Eye stand in a row along the edge of the woods ahead of them. Deluca brandishes his hunting knife. Nickleby, Izod, and Lazy-Eye point their bows and arrows. Panagle holds his walking stick weapon. The wire-haired terrier strains growling at the end of his leash. Deluca jerks him back. The kitten cowers. The sound of a motorcycle guns, and Redford bursts through the trees, pops a wheelie, and skids to a stop. He lifts his goggles. The motor idles. Sam says finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you creeps want? Redford shrugs and answers with a callous smile:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're looking for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because you're a fugitive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm not. Didn't you get my letter of resignation? I quit the Khaki Scouts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're still in uniform. Pause. Sam quickly takes off his shirt and throws it aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it doesn't matter, anyway. You don't have that authority. We've been deputized. Now are you going to come along peacefully or not? Sam takes a deep breath. He pleads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen to some reason: I don't like you. You don't like me. Why don't you stupid idiots just let us disappear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's tempting, but I can't allow it. Deluca spits on the ground. He says to Suzy:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shouldn't be friends with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because he's crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you just don't know him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We know him a lot better than you. He's emotionally disturbed because his family died. Nickleby, tie him up. Nickleby takes a step forward with his bow and arrow pointed and ready. Suzy looks furious. Sam flips his air-rifle off his shoulder with a twirl. He points it at Redford and Nickleby. Nickleby hesitates. Sam says darkly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do not cross this stick. Sam motions to a twig on the ground in front of him. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're doomed, Shakusky. Redford revs the motor, pops the clutch, and races across the clearing toward Sam and Suzy. The rest of the troop converges, yelling crazily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wide canyon echoing with shouts, screams, and a small explosion. One by one, Deluca, Nickleby, Panagle, Izod, and Lazy-Eye come running out of the trees and down the hill. Finally, Redford hobbles after them, limping and groaning and clutching his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redford's charred, partially demolished motorcycle smoldering in the branches of a tree. Suzy stands on the edge of the ravine staring at the pair of bloody scissors in her hand. She looks shaken. Sam takes the scissors, cleans them with his fingers, and hands them back to Suzy. He says gently:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was him or us. Suzy nods. She turns slowly away. Her eyes widen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no. Suzy points. The wire-haired terrier lies on his back on the ground with an arrow sticking out between his shoulder blades. The kitten licks at the wound. Sam and Suzy run over to the wounded dog. Sam crouches down, gently presses the kitten away, and says bleakly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They got Snoopy through the neck. Suzy has tears in her eyes. She slides her hands under the wire-haired terrier's body. She begins to hyperventilate as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He needs a doctor. Sam puts his finger to the wire-haired terrier's neck. He
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, he doesn't. He needs a morgue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying to catch her breath) He's losing blood. Hurry. Where do we go? Suzy lifts the bleeding dog into her arms. Sam grabs her by the shoulders. He locks eyes with her and says with grit and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzy. Look at me. Snoopy's not going to make it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (starting to cry) Don't say that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're after us. We got to move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (raising her voice) He's dying! We can't just leave him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too late! He's already gone!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop yelling at me! Sam slaps Suzy in the face. She falls silent. He says slowly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry I had to do that, but you're panicking. The first rule in any emergency is you never -- Suzy drops the wire-haired terrier which hits the ground with a thud. She slaps Sam back with a huge, roundhouse smack. Sam falls over sideways. Suzy stands over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't ever do that again. No one's allowed to slap me. Sam stands up and dusts himself off. He and Suzy stare down at the lifeless animal. Suzy says quietly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. He's dead. Sam reaches into a side-picket of his back-pack and takes out an army-shovel. He assembles it. Suzy says hopefully:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was he a good dog? Pause. Sam shrugs. He says distantly, even cosmically:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's to say -- but he didn't deserve to die. Suzy slowly wraps her arm around Sam's shoulder. They squeeze each other tightly. Sam sighs. He begins to dig.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Captain Sharp speeds bouncing down a winding dirt road. Lazy- Eye, Deluca, and Gadge sit next to him crowded into the passenger seat. Lazy-Eye yells into the hand-set of the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stabbed Redford in the back with lefty scissors! A voice responds over the speaker:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Repeat that, please? Over. Captain Sharp grabs the hand-set out of Lazy-Eye's hand. He shouts into it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Puncture wound. Lower lumbar. Make room for a stretcher in the cockpit! Redford is lying on his stomach on a towel in the rear of the vehicle. Scout Master Ward kneels next to him pressing his hand firmly into the middle of his back. There is significant blood. Redford moans loudly. Scout Master Ward reassures him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to be OK. Thank goodness, she missed the artery. Bite on this. Scout Master Ward puts a pencil in Redford's teeth. Redford grimaces, crunching it. In the back seat, the rest of the troop excitedly re-cap:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tried to chop him, but he dodged my tomahawk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who else got hit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not me. I ran away when the girl went berserk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got great marksmanship. He shot Deluca in both arms. Skotak points to the front seat. Deluca sits glumly in silence. He has numerous small welts all over his arms. Gadge
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Snoopy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Captain Sharp's station wagon skids to a stop next to his office while the seaplane pulls up to the dock as Mr. and Mrs. Bishop approach pedalling furiously on bicycles. Mr. Bishop wears boating shoes. Captain Sharp and Scout Master Ward jump out of the car. Skotak and Gadge help them remove Redford on a stretcher from the back of the station wagon. Mr. Bishop struggles with his kick-stand. He shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP What happened? Who's that? Why's he bleeding?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clear the dock, Edgar! Captain Sharp motions for the two old fishermen to get out of the way. He and Scout Master Ward run with the stretcher onto the dock. Mrs. Bishop is frantic:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Is Suzy with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, she's in the woods with Shakusky. Gadge points toward the hills. A man wearing a jumpsuit and aviator sunglasses stands next to the seaplane. He is Jed. He shouts as the stretcher approaches:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'm I going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The infirmary at Fort Lebanon. We'll be right behind you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Captain Sharp motions for Skotak, Gadge, and Lazy-eye to help Jed load the stretcher into the small cockpit. He tosses a set of keys to Scout Master Ward and says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warm up the motor. I'll be right back. Scout Master Ward takes the keys and starts untying the police launch. Captain Sharp heads toward his office. Mr. Bishop says firmly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Hold it right there. You're not leaving this island. Our daughter's been abducted by one these beige lunatics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt, it's very clear: the two of them conspired in this together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, Mr. Bishop. She'll be safe. Sam's got excellent wilderness skills. Mr. Bishop wheels on Scout Master Ward. He explodes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Why can't you control your scouts? Scout Master Ward recoils. He says quietly, troubled:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying. Mr. Bishop takes off his shoe and throws it at Scout Master Ward. Scout Master Ward ducks, and the shoe bounces off his back. Captain Sharp blocks Mr. Bishop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop. Mr. Bishop scuffles with Captain Sharp. Mrs. Bishop jerks him backwards and shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP Stop it, Walt! Mr. Bishop faces Mrs. Bishop and Captain Sharp, breathing heavily. Scout Master Ward looks depressed. Jed, Gadge, Skotak, and Redford watch frozen from a gangplank alongside the seaplane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do blame him -- (pointing to Scout Master Ward)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but I also blame myself and both of you. With all due respect: you can't let your children stab people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BISHOP (HESITATES) What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction
